newsitem.title: SOUTH KOREA: Seoul lobby group to demand dividend tax change.
newsitem.headline: Seoul lobby group to demand dividend tax change.

text.p: The Korea Listed Companies' Association said on Thursday it will ask the government to revise tax regulations on dividend income.
A statement complained that investors were currently double-taxed on such income because firms pay tax on profit before dividend payment.
The association wants "unreasonable" tax legislation struck down in the first quarter of 1997 and will draft detailed demands later, the statement said.
The statement did not make clear whether the association will ask for a total tax exemption on dividend income.

It said the association would recommend members pay a higher percentage of their net profit as dividends to shareholders -- 22 percent for manufacturing firms, 31 percent for financial and insurance firms and 24 percent for other non-manufacturing firms.
If those guidelines had been followed in calendar 1995, the average ratio of dividend payment to net profit would have been 26.89 percent instead of 21.33 percent, the statement said.
